column1: Now there was once a maiden whose name was Jorinda. She was prettier than all the pretty girls that ever were seen before
column5: and they were soon to be married. One day they went to walk in the wood
column6: that they might be alone; and Jorindel said
column7: ‘We must take care that we don't go too near to the fairy's castle.' It was a beautiful evening; the last rays of the setting sun shone bright through the long stems of the trees upon the green underwood beneath
column8: and the turtle-doves sang from the tall birches.Jorinda sat down to gaze upon the sun; Jorindel sat by her side; and both felt sad
column9: they knew not why; but it seemed as if they were to be parted from one another for ever. They had wandered a long way; and when they looked to see which way they should go home
column10: they found themselves at a loss to know what path to take.
